lie.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: to be in a position in which your body is flat on the floor, on a bed etc
lie.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: The dog was lying dead on the floor.
He was lying on the bed smoking a cigarette.
Don’t lie in the sun for too long.
For a few minutes he just lay there.
lie.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: to put yourself in a position in which your body is flat on the floor or on a bed
lie.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: She lay back against the pillows.
lie.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: to be in a flat position on a surface
lie.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: The papers were lying neatly on his desk.
lie.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: if a problem, an answer, blame etc lies somewhere, it is caused by, exists, or can be found in that thing, person, or situation
lie.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: The strength of the book lies in the fact that the material is from classroom experience.
Part of the blame must lie with social services.
The difficulty lies in providing sufficient evidence.
the problem/answer etc lies with/in something
And herein lies the key to their achievements.
lie.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: if a town, village, etc lies in a particular place, it is in that place
lie.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: The town lies in a small wooded valley.
The Tasman Sea lies between Tasmania and Australia.
lie.translation[0].definitions[5].defini: if something lies ahead of you, lies in the future etc, it is going to happen to you in the future
lie.translation[0].definitions[5].exampl: I was wondering what lay in store for us.
How will we cope with the difficulties that lie ahead?
A blank and empty future lay before me.
lie.translation[0].definitions[6].defini: to be in a particular state or condition
lie.translation[0].definitions[6].exampl: The town now lay in ruins.
The book lay open on the table.
lie.translation[0].definitions[7].defini: if someone lies in a particular place, they are buried there
lie.translation[0].definitions[7].exampl: Here lies Percival Smythe  (=written on a gravestone).
lie.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: to deliberately tell someone something that is not true
lie.translation[1].definitions[0].note.t: lie through your teeth (=say something that is completely untrue)
lie.translation[1].definitions[0].exampl: I could tell from her face that she was lying.
I would never lie to you.
lie.translation[1].definitions[1].defini: if a picture, account etc lies, it does not show the true facts or the true situation
lie.translation[1].note_box[0].sections[: lie/tell a lie
to deliberately tell someone something that is not true
She had lied to protect her son.
Are you accusing me of telling lies?
fib
to lie, especially about something that is not very important – used especially by children
Dan’s fibbing. I didn’t hit him.
make something up/invent something
to invent a story, explanation etc in order to deceive someone
I didn’t want to go so I made up an excuse and said I was busy.
He invented the tale to prevent his parents from finding out the truth.
mislead
to make someone believe something that is not true by giving them false or incomplete information
The government misled the public over the war.
be economical with the truth
to only tell someone part of the truth – often used when saying indirectly that someone is lying
He admitted that he had perhaps been economical with the truth.
perjure yourself/commit perjury
to tell a lie in a court of law
He had perjured himself in court.
Witnesses will be prosecuted if they commit perjury.
lie.translation[2].definitions[0].defini: something that you say or write that you know is untrue
lie.translation[2].definitions[0].exampl: I always know when he’s telling lies.
I knew that soon she would hear the lies about me.
lie.translation[2].note_box[0].sections[: tell (somebody) a lie
He got into trouble for telling a lie.
believe a lie
How could you believe his lies?
spread lies
How dare you spread such vicious lies?
a complete/total/outright lie
Of course the whole thing was a complete lie.
She didn't want to tell her mother an outright lie.
a white lie
We all have to tell white lies sometimes.
a downright lie
That’s a downright lie. I never said any such thing!
a vicious lie
He told the court that it was a vicious lie from beginning to end.
a blatant lie
He felt sure Adams was not convinced by such blatant lies.
a barefaced lie
How can you stand there and tell me such a barefaced lie?
an elaborate lie
Her parents didn’t realise that it was all an elaborate lie.
a big lie
The lawyer said it was a ‘big lie’ that Jones had not received the message.
a pack of lies
Everything he had told me was a pack of lies.
lie.translation[2].note_box[1].sections[: something you say or write that you know is untrue
Would you tell lies to protect a friend?
The allegation is a complete lie.
white lie
a lie that you tell to avoid upsetting someone
We all tell white lies sometimes.
fib
a lie, especially about something that is not very important – used especially by children
Have you been telling fibs?
porky
a lie – a very informal use
He’s been telling porkies again.
falsehood
a statement that is not true, especially one that is intended to give people the wrong idea about someone or something
He described the allegations as malicious falsehoods.
untruth
a lie – used especially when you want to avoid saying the word lie
Some workers go off and tell untruths about the organisations for which they are working.
fabrication
a story or claim that someone has invented in order to deceive someone, or the act of doing this
The claim was described as a fabrication by the police prosecutor.
He dismissed the charges as pure fabrication.
libel
the crime of writing lies that could make people have a bad opinion of someone, especially in a newspaper or magazine
She sued the newspaper for libel.
libel laws
slander
the crime of speaking lies that could make people have a bad opinion of someone, or an untrue statement which does this
He’s threatening to sue them for slander.
a slander on the good name of the company
Linking his name to terrorism was a slander.
